thread.title: Frustrated parents protest for gun safety in downtown Seattle
thread.title_full: Frustrated parents protest for gun safety in downtown Seattle | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Frustrated parents protest for gun safety in downtown Seattle
text:
Frustrated with gun violence, parents and their children took to the streets in downtown Seattle late Friday afternoon.
Parents and their children and Washington's first lady Trudi Inslee marched down 4th Avenue just as the evening rush hour began, demanding gun safety.
Patrick Wylie's father was shot to death 43 years ago by a man who had recently been released from Western State Mental Hospital.
"When my dad was murdered, it wasn't a commplace thing, and now, it seems more commonplace, and it seems commonplace not to do anything about it," Wylie said.
Melinda Barnes organized the march.
As a student at Garfield High School in the 1990s, she ran into a classroom, when she heard gunshots inside the school.
“My friend Vanessa's sister was shot in the knee and was no longer able to do gymnastics,” she said.
Barnes supports “Extreme Risk” legislation, a bill that would take away for a short time the guns of people who are showing warning signs, like the shooter who killed nine people at the community college in Roseburg.
But gun right advocates in Washington have opposed it.
“Their worry, though, is that a law like this, unless it is narrowly tailored, could disarm the wrong people,” said Dave Workman, of the Second Amendment Foundation. “It could wrongfully disarm somebody who doesn't deserve to be disarmed.”
State Sen. Dave Frockt is hoping to make progress on Extreme Risk legislation when the Legislature convenes next year.
